title: Implement Fabric AI integration for repository analysis
description:
Create internal/analyze/fabric.go for optional AI analysis:

Prerequisites:
- --fabric flag enabled
- Fabric binary available (check --fabric-path or PATH)

Individual Analysis (i key):
1. Fetch repo metadata + README via gh wrapper
2. Construct context string with repo info
3. Execute: echo "$context" | fabric --pattern analyze-repo
4. Capture output
5. Display in modal or append to detail view

Batch Analysis (Shift+I key):
1. Collect all marked repos
2. Construct combined context with all repo metadata
3. Execute: echo "$context" | fabric --pattern analyze-repos-batch
4. Parse output (may include per-repo recommendations)
5. Display summary report in modal

Context format for Fabric:
```
Repository: owner/name
Description: {description}
Language: {language}
Stars: {count}, Forks: {count}
Last Activity: {relative time}
README:
{readme content, truncated if too long}
```

Implementation:
```go
func AnalyzeRepo(repo Repository, readme string, fabricPath string) (string, error)
func AnalyzeRepos(repos []Repository, fabricPath string) (string, error)
func CheckFabricAvailable(fabricPath string) bool
```

Error handling:
- Fabric not installed: show helpful error message
- Fabric execution fails: show error, don't crash
- Timeout after 30 seconds

Async execution via tea.Cmd.

title: Implement archive candidate heuristics
description:
Create internal/analyze/heuristics.go with archive detection logic:

```go
func IsArchiveCandidate(repo Repository) (bool, string)
```

Criteria (return reasons as semicolon-separated string):
1. Age-based:
   - > 730 days (2+ years): 'No activity in 2+ years'
   - > 365 days (1+ year): 'No activity in 1+ year'

2. Engagement-based:
   - StargazerCount == 0 && ForkCount == 0: 'No community engagement'

3. Fork-based:
   - IsFork && DaysSinceActivity > 180: 'Stale fork'

4. Language-based:
   - IsLegacyLanguage(lang) && DaysSinceActivity > 365: 'Legacy language, inactive'

Helper function:
```go
func IsLegacyLanguage(lang string) bool
```
Default legacy languages: PHP, CoffeeScript, Perl, ActionScript, Objective-C (configurable later)

title: Unit tests for relative time formatting
description:
Create test for formatRelativeTime() in internal/tui/table_test.go:

Test formatRelativeTime(t time.Time) string:

Recent times:
- Just now / today: 'today' or '0 days ago'
- 1 day ago: '1 day ago' (singular)
- 2 days ago: '2 days ago' (plural)
- 7 days ago: '7 days ago' or '1 week ago'

Weeks:
- 14 days: '14 days ago' or '2 weeks ago'
- 30 days: '30 days ago' or '1 month ago'

Months:
- 60 days: '60 days ago' or '2 months ago'
- 365 days: '365 days ago' or '1 year ago'

Years:
- 730 days: '730 days ago' or '2 years ago'
- 1000 days: '1000 days ago' or '2+ years ago'

Edge cases:
- Zero time value
- Future date (shouldn't happen, but handle gracefully)
- Very old date (10+ years)

Format consistency:
- Always includes 'ago' suffix
- Numbers are integers (no decimals)
- Consistent pluralization

Note: Decide on format - either always days, or human-readable (weeks/months/years).
Spec shows '823 days ago' so likely always days is preferred.

```go
func TestFormatRelativeTime(t *testing.T) {
    now := time.Now()
    
    tests := []struct {
        name     string
        input    time.Time
        expected string
    }{
        {"today", now, "0 days ago"},
        {"yesterday", now.AddDate(0, 0, -1), "1 day ago"},
        {"week ago", now.AddDate(0, 0, -7), "7 days ago"},
        {"year ago", now.AddDate(-1, 0, 0), "365 days ago"},
    }
    
    for _, tt := range tests {
        t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T) {
            got := formatRelativeTime(tt.input)
            assert.Equal(t, tt.expected, got)
        })
    }
}
```

title: Unit tests for Fabric integration
description:
Create internal/analyze/fabric_test.go:

Test CheckFabricAvailable():
- Returns true when fabric binary exists at path
- Returns true when fabric is in PATH
- Returns false when fabric not found
- Handles custom --fabric-path

Test AnalyzeRepo():
- Constructs correct context string
- Calls fabric with correct arguments
- Returns fabric output on success
- Returns error when fabric fails
- Handles timeout (30 second limit)
- Handles empty README gracefully

Test AnalyzeRepos() (batch):
- Constructs combined context for multiple repos
- Uses batch pattern (analyze-repos-batch)
- Returns combined output
- Handles partial failures

Context construction:
- Includes all required repo metadata
- README is included and truncated if too long
- Format matches expected fabric input

Mock strategy:
- Mock command executor (same as gh wrapper)
- Verify command arguments
- Return canned responses

```go
func TestCheckFabricAvailable(t *testing.T) {
    // Test with mock executor
    mock := &MockExecutor{
        responses: map[string]mockResponse{
            "which fabric": {output: []byte("/usr/local/bin/fabric"), err: nil},
        },
    }
    
    available := CheckFabricAvailable(mock, "")
    assert.True(t, available)
}

func TestAnalyzeRepo(t *testing.T) {
    mock := &MockExecutor{
        responses: map[string]mockResponse{
            "fabric --pattern analyze-repo": {
                output: []byte("Recommendation: Archive this repo..."),
                err: nil,
            },
        },
    }
    
    repo := testutil.NewTestRepo()
    result, err := AnalyzeRepo(mock, repo, "README content", "fabric")
    
    assert.NoError(t, err)
    assert.Contains(t, result, "Recommendation")
}
```
